awd_titl_txt: Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) 2017 Student Support
awd_abstract_narration: This award provides travel funding and conference registration fees for US-based undergraduate and graduate students to attend the 2017 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) to be held in December in San Juan, Puerto Rico. ACSAC is a top-tier academic security conference that regularly brings together the foremost minds in academic, governmental and commercial computer security to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security and discuss seminal works in information security. The broader impact is to facilitate interaction and to groom the next generation of security professionals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. ACSAC is a highly competitive, peer-reviewed conference. The conference program is comprised of two days of tutorials and workshops, and three days of keynote talks, panels, a "works-in-progress" or WIP session, a poster session, and technical paper sessions.

The ACSAC 2017 Student Support project provided NSF funds for ACSAC 2017, which was held in Orlando, FL on December 4-8, 2017, as well as supplemental DHS funds for ACSAC 2018, which was held in San Juan, PR on December 3-7. 2018.

NSF and DHS funds supported students from: U.S. educational institutions; recipients of Scholarships for Women Studying Information Security (SWSIS), which provides assistance to women studying for their Bachelors or Masters degrees in fields relating to information security; and students participating in the pre-conference TracerFIRE training class, a forensic and incident response program developed by Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories. Separate ACSA funding supported students from foreign institutions. All other students attending the conference and/or pre-conference workshops or tutorials received discounted registration fees paid by ACSAC from general registration fees.

The attached table provides statistics on overall ACSAC 2017 and ACSAC 2018 attendance, technical papers, and supported students, including degrees pursued, active roles in the conference, women, and members of underrepresented groups.

ACSAC 2018 featured two keynote talks and supplemental DHS funding was used to support conference fees and travel costs for the keynote speakers: Distinguished Practitioner Keynote: Why Privacy Engineering Matters Now, Michelle Dennedy, Vice President and Chief Privacy Officer, Cisco; and Invited Keynote: AI in Cybersecurity: Applications, Open Problems, and Future Directions, Alina Oprea, Professor of Computer Science, Northeastern University.

A key goal of the ACSAC 2017 Student Support project was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conferences gained valuable insight into current research. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting technical papers, WiPs, and posters. Attendees learned from the students and made connections that could lead to future employment. TracerFIRE provided student attendees a unique opportunity to learn key forensic and incident response skills, and to improve collaboration and teamwork. The invited keynote speeches gave conference attendees leading experts' perspective on applying security to difficult technical problems. Similarly, the tutorials offered attendees a diverse set of classes in key topics areas.

The ACSAC conference is widely publicized and open to all members of the international information security community. The conference proceedings were published by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and are available via the ACM Digital Library. The Proceedings were made freely available to all conference attendees electronically via the ACSAC website.

ACSAC greatly appreciates NSF and DHS support. The conference helps feed the development of new computer and network security technologies and their application to solve address critical security, resilience, and privacy challenges in today's information security systems. By promoting and supporting student participation, tutorial instructors, and keynote speakers, the conference facilitates education and interaction and helps develop and groom the next generation of security professionals.


Last Modified: 05/20/2019
Modified by: David Balenson
